criticalSuccess: With explosive timing, you drive your leg into {targetName}'s ankles with devastating effect. Their feet fly out from under them and they crash to the ground with bone-rattling force, landing hard on their back, the wind knocked completely from their lungs!

You hook {targetName}'s leg at the perfect moment, wrenching it backward as your shoulder drives into their chest. The combination is devastating - they flip backward and slam into the ground with a sickening thud, completely stunned by the violent fall!

Your sweep catches both of {targetName}'s legs in one smooth motion. Their eyes go wide as they realize they're falling with no way to catch themselves. They crash to the ground hard, sprawled and disoriented!

Your trip catches {targetName} off-guard. They stumble, arms windmilling, before dropping to one knee and then going fully prone.

criticalFailure: You commit fully to sweeping {targetName}'s legs, but they jump over your attempted trip with ease. Your own momentum carries you through the failed sweep, and you spin awkwardly, nearly falling yourself. You're left off-balance and exposed!

Your overly ambitious trip attempt is telegraphed and clumsy. {targetName} not only avoids it but uses your poor positioning against you. You stumble, one leg extended awkwardly, barely keeping yourself from hitting the ground!

You sweep your leg with too much force and not enough control. {targetName} steps back casually, and your wild swing throws you completely off balance. You have to catch yourself to avoid falling flat on your face!

criticalSuccess: Like a seasoned warrior, you read {targetName}'s footwork perfectly. Your leg sweeps in with devastating precision, catching their ankle at the exact moment their weight shifts. The physics are inescapable - their feet fly out from under them with violent force. Time seems to slow as shock registers on their face. Then gravity reasserts itself with brutal authority. They crash to the ground with bone-jarring impact, the fall so hard it raises dust. They lie there, stunned and prone, while you stand over them in perfect balance!

Your trip is a masterclass in combat technique. With explosive power, you drive your shin into both of {targetName}'s legs while simultaneously pushing their upper body. The combination is devastating and inescapable. Their legs are swept clean out from under them, and they flip backward through the air before slamming into the ground with terrifying force. The impact echoes. They're not just prone - they're utterly rattled!
success: You execute a solid trip, your leg hooking {targetName}'s ankle at just the right moment. They lose balance and fall, hitting the ground with an audible thump. It's not the most spectacular takedown, but it's effective - they're prone and you're still standing.
With practiced technique, you sweep {targetName}'s leg. They try to catch themselves but fail, ending up on the ground. The trip works exactly as intended - nothing fancy, just good fundamentals.
failure: You attempt to sweep {targetName}'s legs with textbook form, but they read it perfectly. A subtle shift of weight, a small step back, and your trip finds nothing but air. Your technique was flawless, but so was their counter.

Despite your best effort and proper execution, {targetName} simply has better footwork. They dance away from your sweeping leg with frustrating ease, maintaining perfect balance while you're left reaching.
criticalFailure: In your aggressive attempt to trip {targetName}, you overcommit catastrophically. You swing your leg with too much power, too little control, telegraphing the move so obviously that {targetName} sees it coming from a mile away. They don't just avoid it - they practically step over your sweeping leg like it's not even there. Your momentum betrays you. You spin awkwardly, arms pinwheeling as you fight to stay upright. For one mortifying moment, it looks like you're going to trip yourself. You manage to stay standing, but barely, and you're left completely exposed!

Your attempted trip is executed with such poor timing and technique that it borders on comedy. You lunge forward, leg extended at an awkward angle, clearly telegraphing your intention. {targetName} doesn't even have to try hard to avoid it - they simply shift their weight slightly and watch as you sweep at empty air. Your wild swing throws you completely off balance. You stumble forward, nearly falling, arms flailing for equilibrium. What should have been {targetName} on the ground is instead you looking like a fool!

criticalSuccess: You read the larger foe's balance with expert precision. Despite their size, you find their center of gravity - that crucial point where mass becomes liability. Your sweep targets their weight-bearing leg at the perfect moment. With a sharp pull and expert positioning, you use their own mass against them. Physics does the rest. The giant topples with tremendous force, their size making the fall even more devastating!

Size doesn't matter when you understand leverage. You dart in low, positioning yourself at the perfect angle. Your leg hooks behind theirs as you drive forward against their upper body. The combination exploits their high center of gravity beautifully. They try to resist, but their own weight betrays them. They crash to the ground with bone-jarring impact!

Like a master throwing a giant in martial arts, you use technique to overcome size. You find the weak point in their stance, the moment of weight transfer. criticalSuccess: This is David versus Goliath played out in brutal physics. You study the larger foe with the calculating eye of a master, seeing not their intimidating size but their exploitable center of gravity. You move with sudden, explosive precision - darting in low, under their reach. Your leg sweeps behind theirs at the exact moment their weight shifts. Simultaneously, you drive upward against their chest. The leverage is perfect, the timing flawless. For one suspended moment, the giant teeters, their size suddenly becoming their enemy. Then gravity takes over with merciless authority. They don't just fall - they crash, their mass making the impact tremendous. The ground shakes. Dust rises. And they lie there prone and stunned, felled not by strength but by superior technique!

Like a legendary martial artist toppling a giant, you demonstrate the ultimate triumph of skill over size. You don't try to overpower them - that would be madness. Instead, you use physics as your weapon. You find the weakness in their stance, the moment of imbalance inherent in their size. Your sweep is perfectly positioned, targeting their weight-bearing leg with surgical precision. Your upper body push hits their high center of gravity at the exact right angle. The combination is inescapable. Their own mass betrays them. They topple with catastrophic force, arms windmilling uselessly, and slam into the ground hard enough to knock the breath from their lungs. You've just proven that in combat, technique beats size every time!
success: You employ solid technique to trip the larger opponent. Moving with careful precision, you find the angle that lets you exploit their weight distribution. It's not easy - their mass resists your efforts - but your skill prevails. They lose balance and fall to the ground, your leverage overcoming their size advantage.

Your trip uses proper positioning to overcome the size disadvantage. You target their center of gravity at the right moment, applying force where it matters. The larger foe topples to the ground, brought down by technique rather than brute strength.
failure: You move in with sound technique, seeking the leverage point that should let you topple the larger foe. But today, size simply triumphs over skill. Their mass is too great, their balance too stable. Despite your best wrestling technique, they remain standing, immovable as a mountain. Your trip has failed.

Your technical approach is textbook perfect - positioning, timing, leverage all correct. But reality proves unkind. The larger foe's sheer bulk creates challenges your skill simply can't overcome. You can't generate enough force to move their mass. They stay upright while your trip attempt comes to nothing.
criticalFailure: You commit to the trip with complete confidence in your technique. You've studied leverage, practiced positioning, and you're certain you can topple this larger foe. You're catastrophically wrong. You move in, execute your sweep with perfect form, and achieve... nothing. The larger foe doesn't just stay standing - they barely seem to notice your attempt. Their mass is so overwhelming that your technique might as well be a gentle breeze. Worse, your committed position leaves you off-balance. When they shift their weight - not even deliberately, just adjusting their stance - the movement knocks you completely off your footing. You stumble badly, nearly falling, your failed trip leaving you exposed and vulnerable. Size has defeated skill decisively!

Your attempt to trip the giant using leverage and technique becomes a masterclass in failure. You position yourself perfectly, timing your sweep with precision. But when you execute, reality intervenes brutally. Their mass is simply too great. Your sweep connects with their leg and stops dead, like you've tried to sweep a tree trunk. The jarring stop throws off your own balance. You stumble, overextended and awkward, while they remain standing and stable. Your wrestling expertise has been overwhelmed by simple physics, and you're left in a terrible position!
